lexical.definition: Occurs when a word has several meanings

homonymy.definition: When two different words have the same written and phonetic representation, but unrelated meanings and different etymologies

interpretations: An establishment for custody, loan, exchange, or issue of money
A rising ground bordering a lake, river, or sea

polysemy.definition: When a word has several related meanings but one etymology

syntactic.definition: Occurs when a given sequence of words can be given more than one grammatical structure

analytical.definition: When the role of the constituents within a phrase or sentence is ambiguous

attachment.definition: When a particular syntactic constituent can be legally attached to two parts of a sentence

example.text: The police shot the rioters with guns
interpretations: The police used guns to shoot the rioters
The police shot rioters who were armed with guns

coordination.definition: When multiple conjunctions are used or when one conjunction is used with a modifier

examples.text: I saw Peter and Paul and Mary saw me
interpretations: I saw (Peter and Paul) and Mary saw me
I saw Peter and (Paul and Mary saw me)

elliptical.definition: When it is not certain whether or not a sentence contains an omitted element

example.text: Perot knows a richer man than Trump
interpretations: Perot knows a man who is richer than Trump is
Perot knows a man who is richer than any man Trump knows

semantic.definition: Occurs when a sentence has more than one way of reading it within its context although it contains no lexical or structural ambiguity

scope.definition: When quantifiers can have different scoping relations

interpretations: There is one window shared by all rooms
Each room has its own window

pragmatic.definition: Occurs when a sentence has several meanings in the context in which it is uttered

referential.definition: When an anaphor can take its reference from more than one element

example.text: The trucks shall treat the roads before they freeze

deictic.definition: When pronouns, time and place adverbs have more than one reference point in context

example.text: Every student thinks she is a genius
interpretations: Each female student thinks she herself is a genius
Each student thinks some specific woman is a genius

vagueness.definition: A statement is considered vague if it admits borderline cases

measurement.definition: When terms lack precise measurement criteria

generality.definition: Terms that can be made more precise when necessary

role.definition: When a term covers multiple specific roles

scope.definition: When the scope of application is unspecified but can be clarified

language_error.definition: When grammatical mistakes lead to text being interpreted differently than intended

interpretations: Each light has its own switch
All lights share the same switch
